awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Big Data from Small Groups: Learning Analytics and Adaptive Support in Game-based Collaborative Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a research project supporting a new model of Computer Supported Collaborative Learning (CSCL) that combines the advantages of game based learning with problem based learning. Good game based learning environments combine rich scenarios with engaging activities to serendipitously provide student learning. These learning environments also provide an opportunity for players to collaborate in reaching their game goals. Good problem based learning environments provide support for the solution of complex and ill-structured problems. The combination of these two types of learning environments promise to provide the engagement and richness of game based learning with the support environment to engage students in authentic science. Both of these environments are computer based so the actions and interactions of the students and teachers are captured for analysis. Applying learning analytics to the captured data provides information on student learning for the teacher, provides learning information to the student for self-reflection and improved learning, and provides information for the system designer to improve the effectiveness of the new CSCL environment.

The scientific problem domain is environmental science for middle school students. The CSCL environment is a  game based learning environment that incorporates problem based learning. The interaction between the CSCL environment and the student is enhanced by the collection of data on the student based on cognitive, affective, and metacognitive states that are inferred using artificial intelligence technologies. Specific strategies are employed to help students construct explanagions, reason effectively, and become self-directed learners. Key outcomes of the project include a model of collaborative scaffolding for game based learning that is usable in classrooms to help students learn STEM content and learning analytics designed to support the teacher in the roles of guide and collaborator. A goal of the project is wide dissemination of the CSCL system.

por.por_cntn:
Game-based learning offers significant potential for creating rich problem-based learning experiences for science education. This project centered on the investigation of a new family of game-based learning environments and collaborative game-based learning environments that combine the advantages of game-based learning with computer-supported collaborative learning. As groups of students solve problems in these environments, their actions generate rich, dynamic streams of fine-grained multi-channel data that can be instrumented for investigating students' learning processes and outcomes. Using the big data generated by small groups, we harnessed learning analytics to investigate how to provide adaptive support for collaboration to enable collaborative game-based learning environments to be broadly adopted.

We investigated collaborative game-based learning in the context of a game-based learning environment for environmental science, EcoJourneys, which employs specific strategies to support the problem-based learning goals of helping students construct explanations based on scientific evidence, reason effectively, and become self-directed learners who collaboratively negotiate meaning. The EcoJourneys learning environment includes a tutorial and three quests that engage learners in game-based problem-based learning designed to teach middle school students ecosystems and systems thinking concepts. In the tutorial, students are transported to a fictionalized island in the Philippines that relies on tilapia farming, and they are oriented to the central problem: something is wrong and there is widespread suffering among the tilapia, posing significant risk to the population's survival. Students are asked to conduct investigations and develop evidence-based explanations for what can explain the suffering of the tilapia.

The EcoJourneys collaborative game-based learning environment incorporates collaboration functionalities, including an in-game chat system, a collaborative workbook environment, and a virtual whiteboard. The chat system enables students working together to communicate with each other within the game-based learning environment. It also provides scaffolding based on the students' chat participation.The game's Deduce App is a collaborative workbook where students must discuss and reach agreement on answers to questions with respect to interpreting relevant data, and then summarize their decision. The TIDE Board is a virtual whiteboard that the students use to organize evidence they have gathered, including their Deduce App answers, into two categories that either support or do not support a proposed hypothesis for addressing the central problem. The project also saw the creation of a teacher dashboard framework that monitors both individual and group progress in real-time by observing game events from all interacting students' learning environments.

The project has made significant contributions to our understanding of how to design effective collaborative game-based learning environments and how students can effectively learn in these environments. Through studies of the EcoJourneys collaborative game-based learning environment with middle school students in public school classrooms in two states, the project's results include the following: (1) a learning analytics approach to understanding collaborative inquiry in collaborative game-based learning; (2) a discourse analysis model for accurately detecting disruptive talk; (3) explorations of how to design for equitable participation in collaborative game-based learning; (4) empirically-based designs for supporting collaboration in game-based learning environments, including supporting student discussion and consensus-building; (5) facilitation strategies for socially-shared regulated in collaborative game-based problem solving; (6) exploration of participation patterns in problem-based learning through an epistemic lens and collaboration patterns in collaborative game-based learning; and (7) an investigation of coordination among learners in small groups, including analysis of coordination types and thematic analyses of conversational patterns. In addition, the project developed computational models for detecting collaborative phenomena, including a model for detecting out-of-domain talk and a multidimensional stealth assessment model for jointly predicting students' out-of-domain contributions to group chat as well as their learning outcomes.
